paragraphs.text: Assad's crumbling presidency.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Syria's existence as a country continues to haemorrhage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its people flee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: borders disappear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: cities crumble
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The country's heritage is being dug up, stolen or blasted to smithereens and the most effective armed groups in the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: whether ISIL or Hezbollah on the ground or Israel and US in the air, operate under flags that are not Syria's own
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Syria has become a stage for a plethora of violent actors and at the centre is the seemingly immovable object of President Bashar al-Assad, the 49-year-old who has been in power since 2000 following three decades of his father's rule
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The brutal events in Paris have sparked another conversation across global media on the scourge of Islamic terrorism and led the Independent's Middle East correspondent, Patrick Cockburn, to suggest that people forget about overthrowing Assad and instead should concentrate on building a common cause with Damascus that "could unite against violent Sunni jihadism"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while Assad is still there nominally in power
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: a closer look reveals that he is more marginalised than ever and an increasingly irrelevant political actor on a stage dominated by others
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This authoritarian facade must be taken into account in future policy towards the beleaguered country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Start by
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: asking the question
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what is Assad still president of?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Half of the country have fled their homes
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: over 200,000 are dead
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a million are wounded
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The UN estimates that it will cost $8.4bn in 2015 to look after Syrians affected by war
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: more than 6,500 cases of typhoid and 4,200 cases of measles were reported in 2014
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Although"government forces" are supposedly in control of some 50 percent of the territory
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: the devolution of power to militias as well as Iranian and Hezbollah forces means that Assad's command and control is stretched like never before
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Meanwhile in the east, ISIL runs a bus network out if its capital Raqqa
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: despite Kobane being in stalemate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the Kurds are increasingly sketching out the makings of a statelet in the northeast of the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The country's borders are disappearing as functional entities with talk of a Turkish buffer zone in the north and all sorts of foreign fighters (and John McCain) entering the country at will
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A recent Middle East Eye report outlined that the "Syrian economy has effectively ceased to function, and President Bashar al-Assad's government is almost entirely dependent on loans from Iran and some aid from the Russian Federation"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Towards the end of last year the desperate position saw Damascus even issue a new "Martyrs Stamp Duty"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: whose proceeds will go to the families of fallen soldiers and other militia members
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Aleppo, the country's largest city and once commercial hub, is being pummelled by a regular supply of barrel bombs with the hospitals being forced underground and ISIL forces closing in
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Assad himself is seen less and less
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On a New Year's Eve trip to
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: was said
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: to be "the frontlines" in his own capital
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the president's smiles and patriotic music couldn't disguise the occasional crack of background gunfire
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Several days later the Assad publicity blitz continued with a very public appearance at a prayer in a mosque in Damascus
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The New York Times were so surprised to see him that they pointed out he'd shaved his moustache
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: although others claimed it has simply gone white, perhaps due the stress of the continued conflict
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the focus on Assad the individual, rather than Syria the country, and the narrative of government against the opposition, doesn't explain the hollowing out of the former and the fragmentation of the latter
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This time last year the Geneva II Peace Conference marked the high water mark of the Syrian opposition as a coherent and seemingly viable actor
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Since then, the corrosiveness of ISIL's rapid spread and the increased brutality of the conflict has seemingly made an immoderate crisis an impossible place for moderate actors such as the FSA and the National Syrian Coalition
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Khaled Khoja was elected the new leader of the coalition at the start of the year and quickly signalled his unwillingness for them to attend another attempt at peace talks, this time organised by Russia
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: What Syria is and what it could eventually become will have regional and global ramifications that are hard to predict
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Among the most unlikely scenarios is the return of a unitary state with full control of territory within its borders under the effective sovereignty of Assad
paragraphs.label: assumption
